children.text: Good things are happening! Democratic voters in Pennsylvania and Oregon flipped off party leaders and their super PAC donors by choosing anti-establishment progressives over corporate Democrats in this week’s primaries. Also, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is giving states more power to hunt down bad actors, unionization efforts nationwide are flourishing, and the Biden admin green-lit another round of free at-home COVID tests.
All this and much more in this week’s edition of You Love To See It, exclusively for supporting subscribers below.
One Nation, Underdog
Much to the chagrin of corporate Democrats and their super PAC donors, progressives in Pennsylvania and Oregon miraculously eked out wins in Tuesday’s primaries.
Pennsylvania state Rep. Summer Lee, an anti-fracking progressive running in the 12th congressional district, won in Tuesday’s Democratic primary against former Republican U.S. Senate staffer and
union-avoidance lawyer
Steve Irwin. Lee’s win in fracking country came as a pleasant surprise, especially given the
more than $3.4 million
that outside groups tied to pro-Israel American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC) poured into the race.

children.text: “Our victory shows that we can overcome the billionaire class that wants to divide and conquer us all with fear and lies-for-profit, if only we come together across our differences for a positive vision of multiracial democracy,” Lee
tweeted
. “We can have nice things, if we fight.”
Also in Pennsylvania, Lt. Gov. John Fetterman, whose campaign survived attacks from a
health insurance-aligned super PAC

, beat conservative Democratic Rep. Conor Lamb in the Senate primary. Fetterman’s victory came despite Lamb receiving the establishment’s support and Fetterman having surgery to implant a pacemaker on Election Day following a stroke he had last Friday. Fetterman has voiced his support for a host of progessive priorities, from universal health care to recreational marijuana legalization. It’s worth noting, however, that Fetterman supports fracking and that he intends, if elected this November, to
help bolster
the cozy relationship between the U.S. and Israel.
In Oregon, Rep. Kurt Schrader, a Biden- and
Big Pharma-backed
Dem representing the state’s 5th congressional district, is likely to lose his seat to progressive challenger Jamie McLeod-Skinner, once Clackamas County’s ballots have
all been counted
. Results should be in by next week.

Also in Oregon, state Rep. Andrea Salinas, who was backed by the Working Families Party and other national and local progressive groups, won her congressional primary against Carrick Flynn in district 6 — a stunning upset, given the
$13 million
in super PAC spending for Flynn. If Salinas wins in November’s general election, she will be the first Latina representing Oregon in Congress.
The progressive candidates’ success follows new polling data showing
Democratic voters are disgruntled
with their party’s incrementalism.
A Win For Consumers
Yesterday, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), the agency charged with protecting Americans from bad actors in the financial sector,
announced a rule

making clear that state regulators and attorneys general can go after companies and individuals that violate federal consumer financial protection laws — such as the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which protects information collected by consumer reporting agencies.

“In the years leading up to the financial crisis, federal regulators undermined states seeking to protect families and businesses from abuses in the mortgage market,” said CFPB Director Rohit Chopra. “Our action today demonstrates our commitment to promoting state enforcement, not suffocating it.”
State Of The Unions
•  On Thursday, there were union victories at
three Starbucks
locations in Colorado; one at a Starbucks in Waban, Massachusetts; and one in Newport News, Virginia. In total,
more than 80
Starbucks stores have been unionized. Kudos to Starbucks Workers United! To help support SWU’s efforts,
click here
to chip in for Starbucks workers’ bills while they strike against illegal union-busting in Columbia, South Carolina.
•  The National Labor Relations Board told Amazon Labor Union — the nascent group responsible for the Staten Island Amazon warehouse win last month — that it plans to bring
a new complaint against Amazon
for additional
labor law violations

. Those potential violations include the company allegedly holding illegal captive audience meetings, telling employees who signed union authorization cards that they would give up their right to speak for themselves, and threatening to withhold benefits from employees, among other illegal activity.
•  Journalists at
The Hill
are seeking to unionize and
just requested
voluntary recognition of The Hill Guild from Nexstar Media.
•  On Thursday, Amherst Cinema Workers United
received
notice of voluntary recognition.
•  Labor reporter Alex Press wrote a
great piece
on budding unionization efforts across the retail sector, including at Apple, REI, and Target.
Wait, Biden Actually Did Something?
The Biden admin opened another round of free home COVID-19 tests that folks can order
here
. Each order includes eight rapid antigen tests, and shipping is free.
Earlier this week, Biden also
announced
that his administration will invoke the Defense Production Act to accelerate baby formula production. Now,
if only
he could use the DPA to help the solve other crises, like our destructive fossil fuel dependence or a
lack of COVID vaccines
in many countries around the world.
Want To Get Involved?
•  The Tops supermarket in Buffalo, where the devastating shooting by a
white supremacist
occurred last weekend, is a crucial source of groceries and community resources. Because of the
physical and emotional toll

the mass shooting has taken on members of the predominantly Black neighborhood in which it occurred, it’s worth contributing to the Buffalo Community Fridge, if able. Their Venmo handle is @bflocommunityfridge.
•  In light of the
Washington Post
editorial board
demanding the arrests
of protesters peacefully demonstrating outside Supreme Court justices’ homes based on the leaked draft opinion to overturn
Roe v. Wade
, media watchdog group FAIR is asking people to let the
Post
know that “repression of peaceful assembly is incompatible with democracy.” You can find more information
here
•  Urge the Manhattan District Attorney to
drop all charges
against Tracy McCarter, a Black woman who was charged with murder for defending herself against her abusive partner in March of 2020.
